abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sichuan Provincial
            Highway Project for China were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            restructuring of the project was warranted, as was a
            mid-term review, and given the delays in project
            implementation, field supervision should have continued
            until project closing. For components which could not be
            launched, even after an elapse of one or two years, a
            decision should have been taken to restructure or cancel the
            components. The tools used for project management, including
            supervision reports, progress and audit reporting, and
            procurement tracking, should have been more realistic and
            explicit, reflecting changes and implementation difficulties
            in the project. Supervision intensity, including the skills
            and level of staffing needed for effective supervision and
            the frequency of field supervision, were less than adequate
            in this project. The technical aspects of expressway design,
            road management systems, and road safety are all areas which
            may have benefited from greater assistance by the Bank.

18150866.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sichuan Provincial Highway Project
            will assist the Government in meeting the road transport
            demand in the most important and congested corridor in
            Sichuan Province and in improving management of the
            provincial road network by introducing modern planning and
            management techniques, including training. Specifically the
            project comprises, the construction of a 340km high-standard
            highway between Chengdu and Chongqing and the reconstruction
            of 105km of key rural roads. The project will finance
            technical assistance for the introduction of improved road
            planning by starting preparation of a road data bank, and
            the introduction of paved road evaluation as a basis for a
            pavement strengthening program. The loan will provide for
            staff training in the various fields of the road subsector.
            Finally, the loan will finance assistance in highway related
            research and modernization of design, construction and
            materials specifications, and in civil works contract documentation.
